INTJ.title: The Architect
INTJ.summary: INTJs are strategic, independent thinkers who value logic and long-term vision. They prefer to work alone or in small groups and are driven by their inner world of ideas and possibilities.

behaviors.title: Strategic planning
behaviors.description: They naturally see patterns and outcomes, and enjoy designing systems and plans that achieve long-term goals efficiently.

behaviors.title: Independence
behaviors.description: INTJs trust their own analysis over consensus and prefer to make decisions without needing constant approval from others.

behaviors.title: High standards
behaviors.description: They hold themselves and others to high standards of competence and can be blunt when expectations are not met.

INTP.title: The Thinker
INTP.summary: INTPs are logical, innovative, and curious. They love exploring abstract ideas and building mental models of how the world works, often losing track of time in analysis.

behaviors.title: Abstract thinking
behaviors.description: They excel at understanding complex theories and enjoy debating ideas for the sake of clarity and precision.

behaviors.title: Flexibility
behaviors.description: INTPs prefer to keep options open and may delay decisions until they have explored all logical possibilities.

behaviors.title: Detachment
behaviors.description: They can appear aloof because they prioritize logical consistency over emotional considerations in discussions.

ENTJ.title: The Commander
ENTJ.summary: ENTJs demonstrate a preference for extraverted thinking (Te) combined with introverted intuition (Ni), resulting in a leadership style characterized by strategic planning, systematic organization, and goal-oriented decision-making. They structure their external environment through clear hierarchies and efficient processes.

behaviors.title: Natural leadership
behaviors.description: The dominant Te function drives ENTJs to organize systems and people toward defined objectives. This cognitive preference manifests as a tendency to assume leadership positions where they can implement structure and hold others accountable to established standards and timelines.

behaviors.title: Decisiveness
behaviors.description: The Te-Ni combination enables rapid assessment of options against strategic goals, leading to efficient decision-making processes. ENTJs typically favor moving forward with action rather than extended deliberation, as their cognitive framework prioritizes implementation and measurable outcomes.

behaviors.title: Direct communication
behaviors.description: Extraverted thinking emphasizes clarity and efficiency in communication, resulting in straightforward, task-focused exchanges. When ENTJs prioritize results and organizational effectiveness, their communication style may be perceived as demanding or impersonal by those who prioritize relationship harmony or emotional considerations.

ENTP.title: The Debater
ENTP.summary: ENTPs are quick-witted, clever, and resourceful. They love intellectual challenges, enjoy playing devil's advocate, and thrive on new ideas and possibilities.

behaviors.title: Argumentative enjoyment
behaviors.description: They often debate not to win but to explore ideas; they enjoy the mental exercise and uncovering flaws in reasoning.

behaviors.title: Innovation
behaviors.description: ENTPs generate many ideas and enjoy starting projects, though they may lose interest before finishing details.

behaviors.title: Adaptability
behaviors.description: They think on their feet and can pivot quickly when new information or opportunities appear.

INFJ.title: The Advocate
INFJ.summary: INFJs are creative, insightful, and principled. They seek meaning in relationships and ideas, and often feel a strong sense of purpose to help others.

behaviors.title: Insight into people
behaviors.description: They often understand others' motivations and feelings before they are expressed, and value deep, authentic connections.

behaviors.title: Idealistic vision
behaviors.description: INFJs hold strong values and work toward a vision of how things could be better, sometimes at the cost of their own comfort.

behaviors.title: Need for privacy
behaviors.description: Despite caring about people, they need significant alone time to recharge and process their rich inner experience.

INFP.title: The Mediator
INFP.summary: INFPs are empathetic, creative, and idealistic. They are guided by their values and seek to live in harmony with what they believe is right and meaningful.

behaviors.title: Value-driven choices
behaviors.description: They make decisions based on personal values and authenticity rather than pure logic or social pressure.

behaviors.title: Creative expression
behaviors.description: INFPs often express themselves through writing, art, or other creative outlets that reflect their inner world.

behaviors.title: Avoidance of conflict
behaviors.description: They prefer to avoid confrontation and may struggle to assert their needs in order to keep peace.

ENFJ.title: The Protagonist
ENFJ.summary: ENFJs are charismatic, inspiring, and natural leaders. They care deeply about others and work to help people grow and achieve their potential.

behaviors.title: Natural encouragement
behaviors.description: They see potential in others and actively encourage and support people to reach their goals.

behaviors.title: Organizing people
behaviors.description: ENFJs enjoy bringing people together, facilitating harmony, and creating environments where others can thrive.

behaviors.title: Sensitivity to criticism
behaviors.description: They invest heavily in relationships and can be hurt when their efforts are rejected or criticized.

ENFP.title: The Campaigner
ENFP.summary: ENFPs are enthusiastic, creative, and sociable. They see possibilities everywhere and love connecting with people and exploring new experiences.

behaviors.title: Enthusiasm and energy
behaviors.description: They bring energy and optimism to projects and people, and often inspire others with their excitement.

behaviors.title: Exploration of ideas
behaviors.description: ENFPs enjoy starting new projects and exploring many options; they may struggle with follow-through on routine tasks.

behaviors.title: People-focused
behaviors.description: They value relationships highly and seek meaningful connections; they are often perceptive about others' feelings.

ISTJ.title: The Logistician
ISTJ.summary: ISTJs are practical, reliable, and methodical. They value facts, tradition, and duty, and work steadily to get things done correctly.

behaviors.title: Reliability
behaviors.description: They keep their commitments, follow through on tasks, and expect the same from others.

behaviors.title: Fact-based decisions
behaviors.description: ISTJs prefer to rely on proven methods and concrete data rather than theory or speculation.

behaviors.title: Structure and order
behaviors.description: They work best with clear rules, schedules, and expectations and can be frustrated by constant change.

ISFJ.title: The Protector
ISFJ.summary: ISFJs are warm, responsible, and conscientious. They care for others through practical support and loyalty and take their commitments seriously.

behaviors.title: Practical care
behaviors.description: They show care through actions—remembering details, helping with tasks, and ensuring others are comfortable.

behaviors.title: Loyalty
behaviors.description: ISFJs are deeply loyal to family, friends, and institutions and may have difficulty letting go of past commitments.

behaviors.title: Avoiding the spotlight
behaviors.description: They often work behind the scenes and may not seek recognition, though they appreciate being valued.

ESTJ.title: The Executive
ESTJ.summary: ESTJs are organized, practical, and decisive. They take charge, enforce rules, and work to create order and efficiency in their environment.

behaviors.title: Direct leadership
behaviors.description: They lead by setting clear expectations, organizing tasks, and holding people accountable for results.

behaviors.title: Tradition and rules
behaviors.description: ESTJs value established procedures and can be skeptical of change that seems to ignore proven methods.

behaviors.title: Practical focus
behaviors.description: They focus on what works in the real world and may dismiss ideas that seem unrealistic or overly theoretical.

ESFJ.title: The Consul
ESFJ.summary: ESFJs are caring, social, and community-minded. They work to create harmony, support others, and maintain positive relationships in their groups.

behaviors.title: Social harmony
behaviors.description: They notice and respond to others' needs and work to keep the group cohesive and happy.

behaviors.title: Responsibility to others
behaviors.description: ESFJs feel responsible for the well-being of those around them and may sacrifice their own needs to help.

behaviors.title: Sensitivity to rejection
behaviors.description: They care deeply about being liked and accepted and can be hurt by conflict or criticism from others.

ISTP.title: The Virtuoso
ISTP.summary: ISTPs are bold, practical, and experimental. They prefer to understand how things work through hands-on experience and enjoy solving problems with tools and logic.

behaviors.title: Hands-on problem solving
behaviors.description: They learn by doing and enjoy taking things apart, fixing them, or building with concrete materials.

behaviors.title: Calm under pressure
behaviors.description: ISTPs often stay cool in crises and focus on immediate, practical solutions rather than emotions.

behaviors.title: Independence
behaviors.description: They value freedom and minimal interference and may resist being tied down by too many rules or commitments.

ISFP.title: The Adventurer
ISFP.summary: ISFPs are flexible, charming, and artistic. They live in the present, value beauty and authenticity, and prefer to express themselves through action rather than words.

behaviors.title: Present-focused
behaviors.description: They prefer to experience life as it happens and may avoid long-term planning in favor of spontaneity.

behaviors.title: Aesthetic sensitivity
behaviors.description: ISFPs often have a strong appreciation for aesthetics—art, nature, or style—and may express themselves through creative outlets.

behaviors.title: Conflict avoidance
behaviors.description: They dislike confrontation and may withdraw or accommodate to keep peace rather than assert their views.

ESTP.title: The Entrepreneur
ESTP.summary: ESTPs are energetic, perceptive, and spontaneous. They thrive on action, enjoy taking risks, and are skilled at reading people and situations in the moment.

behaviors.title: Action-oriented
behaviors.description: They prefer to learn by doing and may become restless when forced to sit through long theory or planning without action.

behaviors.title: Quick thinking
behaviors.description: ESTPs think on their feet and can adapt quickly to new information or changing circumstances.

behaviors.title: Risk-taking
behaviors.description: They often enjoy excitement and may take calculated risks in business, sports, or social situations.

ESFP.title: The Entertainer
ESFP.summary: ESFPs are spontaneous, energetic, and enthusiastic. They love to have fun, bring people together, and live in the moment with optimism and warmth.

behaviors.title: Fun and spontaneity
behaviors.description: They enjoy creating a good time for others and often have a natural talent for entertaining and lifting moods.

behaviors.title: People-focused
behaviors.description: ESFPs are attentive to others' reactions and work to make people feel included and happy.

behaviors.title: Present-oriented
behaviors.description: They focus on the here and now and may find long-term planning or abstract discussion less engaging.
